previous.text: any one heard or seen cases where Tanium client is causing battery drain based on OSX firewall and all the P2P connections? Customer has made loose observation that “since Tanium was installed my battery life has been worse’. While we haven’t been provided any actual metrics or evidence at this point the observation is being made by the CSO at a time when Tanium seems to be getting blamed for _any_ issue that arises. Their conclusion is based on seeing OSX FW using more battery and lots of logs for the FW around Tanium :confused: With that, they are now asking for Tanium best practice to whitelist Tanium client with the OSX firewall. Seems to me that port based exception might be a good option but wanted to see if anyone else has thoughts/ideas/recommendations?

attachments.fallback: @michael-ericson-tanium a solid suggesting. the `raw` subcommand does a raw pretty print of the JSON now. I wonder if I could add a global `--raw` to all of the REST-based commands to also skip the DTO interpretation and just go right to the pretty print. One thing I like about printing the unmarshalled response is it's cleaner and nulls are removed, but I definitely see the value of seeing the whole response for a new property we forgot to add. Logging may also fix that too as it shows the payload.

attachments.title: Pull Request #649: "Fix import bindings for TaskResult/TaskStatus."

attachments.fallback:
Super handy!  I haven't reviewed all of it because there's so much but here are some general design thoughts:

1. Instead of binding tightly to the DTOs it would be nice to display the raw response (maybe even pretty print with a flag) to reduce the maintenance load (i.e. new DTOs, changes, etc) and any second-guessing about interpretation of the data.  Of course, that would require paging so it might not fit the interactive console model.

1. Might be cool to break out `taniumApi` as a separate project for other golang Tanium programs.

I vote we ship it with future versions as a debugging tool :+1:
attachments.text:
Super handy!  I haven't reviewed all of it because there's so much but here are some general design thoughts:

1. Instead of binding tightly to the DTOs it would be nice to display the raw response (maybe even pretty print with a flag) to reduce the maintenance load (i.e. new DTOs, changes, etc) and any second-guessing about interpretation of the data.  Of course, that would require paging so it might not fit the interactive console model.

1. Might be cool to break out `taniumApi` as a separate project for other golang Tanium programs.

I vote we ship it with future versions as a debugging tool :+1:

@connyay One thing I'd love your input on is whether we should break this into a separate repro. I think you have the opinion that maybe the tanium soap/client stuff could/should be separate but maybe the product ones not? Or maybe each of those on its own merit? Not a critical choice for now, but something I'd like to use this PR to discuss.

Also, the general organization of golang feels funky to me and I'm sure I could organize this better. If we break into a different repro, the organization would be quite different for sure. Either way, comments to the code organization would be welcome.

So, this is totally not a request to merge into `develop` per se, as much as it is an opportunity to explore this code for different possibliities.

Maybe we go open source just to expose the various APIs?

Maybe we create a separate project for just TaniumDetectCLI?

Maybe we make it a full-blown TaniumCLI?

Maybe my organization of the code is completely not gloang-y :) ?

Let's talk about it, play with it, and see where it goes. The night is young.

attachments.title: cmd/link: segfault with statically linked binaries on linux · Issue #13470 · golang/go · GitHub
attachments.text: Discovered with @tschottdorf. package main import ( "net" "os/user" "C" ) func main() { for i := 0; i < 1000; i++ { _, _ = net.Dial("tcp", "localhost:1337") _, _...
attachments.fallback: GitHub: cmd/link: segfault with statically linked binaries on linux · Issue #13470 · golang/go

previous_2.text:
<@U02QM5B4Q>:  <@U026E47D7> We’re not the only ones who’ve run into this. 
It turns out it’s a bug with libc along the lines of what I was thinking <https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=19341>. (This was filed by the golang folks <https://github.com/golang/go/issues/13470>).

In this specific case, the shared-library instance of libc won’t initialize the required ctypes data if the statically-linked libc has already created a thread. libc only ever expects there to be one instance in memory at a time, so they’ve no way to accommodate for one-another. 

The maintainers of libc *don’t* know how to fix the issue, as there are other problems associated with having both a statically-linked libc and shared-library libc in memory at the same time. They recommend dynamically linking to libc rather than statically, and go on further to suggest that if you are going to statically link, that should be limited to being done within binaries that do not make heavy usage of the libc feature set.

next.text: I don't think we want the client dynamically linked.

next_2.text: I wonder if we can force Python to statically link?

matches.text: I was generally under the impression that this sort of thing was okay as long as you didn't mismatch memory allocation stuff (static alloc, dynamic free, vice versa)

previous.text: Ipc options for like vbscript sensors have been terrible and I'm sure we could abuse the names pipes pretty frequently.

previous_2.text: I'd love to see you do named pipes as they are pretty interesting for cheating stuff. Many times I've thought about using them in golang or even vbscript content but haven't done it. It would be rad to get a look at how to implement them well in Python

next.text: the thing that’s helpful is the PeekNamedPipe method, which let’s you see if there’s any data available

next_2.text: Are we going to show this at TNTi? I can sign is up. I am also showing our test automation framework that has been taking most of my time
